awd_titl_txt: Acquisition of a Confocal Microscope for New Research and Teaching
awd_abstract_narration:
An award is made to Wesleyan University to support the acquisition of a confocal microscope for use by faculty and students across multiple departments and disciplines.  The new instrument will profoundly enhance the training environment and be used during many highly interactive laboratory courses taught by Wesleyan faculty to promote STEM career advancement. The proposed microscope will be housed in an advanced imaging facility that includes scanning and transmission electron microscopes. To support dissemination of science to the general public, as exemplified by the large number of articles authored by Wesleyan faculty that are printed in the popular media, data generated by the new system will be used in outreach presentations, science camps, local high-schools, an annual scientific imaging student prize, and similar forums.
 
Wesleyan boasts an unusually broad portfolio of research topics that will benefit from the new system, including evolution and development of morphology, optogenetic-based control of behavior, cell biology, physiology, developmental neuroscience, and chromosomal dynamics. Each of these areas is experiencing an expansion of research into spatial relationships, driven by advances in microscopy, and by the realization that researchers must study three-dimensional shapes and how those change over time to understand the structure and function of biological systems.  Several of the research projects will only be possible because the local availability of the system. Data and analyses from these studies will be published in peer-reviewed scientific journals, presented at scientific meetings, and used in both educational and public outreach activities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Wesleyan University and other regional colleges now have a confocal microscope of unparalleled resolution with increased spectral detection, greater sensitivity and more rapid scanning speeds. We have expanded the number of users benefiting from advanced microscopy while also expanding the number and types of research that can be performed at Wesleyan. We have maintained and expanded internationally recognized scholarship.

Teaching and Mentoring

The Leica SP8 microscope supports our commitment to excellence in training and professional development. The instrument is used by undergraduates and graduate students in formal courses such as Neurohistology, and extensively in individual mentored research projects. Each of the 13 research groups that have used the SP8 purchased with this MRI grant have graduate students and multiple undergraduates. These students have received one-on-one training in microscopy by the microscopy specialist, and one-on-one mentoring by the principal investigator. This training resulted in increased knowledge and skill in the area of microscopy, and in the specific research area of the students' research. 

Each summer, Wesleyan’s College of Integrative Sciences (CIS)  runs a summer research program across the sciences that hosts more than 100 Wesleyan undergraduates.  In addition to faculty mentored research, we offer a weekly seminar series and skills workshops, including intensive one-on-one training for students interested in research using the  Leica microscope.The Wesleyan Scientific Imaging Contest, held annually in August, recognizes student-submitted images—from experiments or simulations done with a Wesleyan faculty member—that are scientifically intriguing, as well as aesthetically pleasing. The contest is organized by the College of Integrative Sciences as part of the summer research program. In this contest, the panel of judges look for images that reflect both the art and the science of the object of study. Confocal images have figured prominently in the winning images.

Research

Research projects supported by the Leica SP8 microscope include a diversity of model systems and research questions. These include the evaluation of stem cell therapy in rodent models of disease, allelic exclusion in olfactory receptor gene expression, the molecular basis for cell shape changes in sculpting embryonic tissues, the embryonic development of muscle stem cells, the genetics of spine patterning, and the cellular mechanisms that drive chromosome dynamics during the differentiation of sex cells. 

In addition to fostering greater advancements in these existing projects, the Leica SP8 microscope facilitated the recruitment of four new tenure track faculty. One is a neuroscientist who uses the microscope to study the cellular and molecular basis for changes in brain circuitry following alcohol abuse. Another is a neurochemist who uses the microscope to study stem cell and zebrafish models of motor neuron degeneration. A third is a biochemist working on the role of metal ion binding proteins in muscle and other cells. Finally, Wesleyan has recently hired a cell biologist who will make extensive use of the instrument to study collective cellular migration, which is essential to the sculpting of multicellular organisms, closure of wounds, and tumor metastasis. All of these life scientists and their students will utilize the Leica SP8 for research.

Broader Impacts and Outreach

Wesleyan has a long-standing commitment to diversity, at the undergraduate, graduate and faculty levels. Demonstrating our commitment to addressing underrepresentation in the scientific workforce all four of the recently-recruited tenure-track faculty that utilize confocal microscopy for their research are women and three are members of underrepresented minorities in science. We have communities of scholars in the sciences to recruit and retain URM students in STEM fields, including the McNair program and WesMass. The Ronald E. McNair Post Baccalaureate Achievement (McNair Scholars) Program provides experiences that prepare students for graduate education in all STEM disciplines. The program involves junior and senior undergraduate students in research, mentoring, and other scholarly activities.  McNair participants are from diverse backgrounds and have demonstrated strong academic potential.

 

The university received a generous donation that will fund financial aid for qualified BA/MA students beginning with entry term Fall 2022.  Applicants receiving Wesleyan grant aid during the final year of the BA program qualify for financial aid for the two semesters of the MA.  The goal of financial aid is to ensure that participation in the program is not limited for financial reasons. Students and faculty mentors from these programs provide mentoring, research opportunities and community building efforts to increase and retain students of color and women in many critical areas of the biomedical sciences that require strong quantitative skills. Many of these mentors and trainees will be exposed to major instrumentation, such as the confocal microscope and our other advanced microscopic imaging instrumentation funded by the NSF.
